instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-02020: What is 820-02020? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.A2338: What is A2338? A2338 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Late 2020 M1, Mid 2022 M2 with EMC 8162, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-02020, 820-02773..
definitions.CD3217: What is CD3217? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.PP3V3_S2: What is PP3V3_S2? PP3V3_S2 is a typo of PP3V3_S3.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Stuck at 5V 0.46A draw
threads.message:
So a little bit of backstory on this one I received an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2338</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> in for repair again. 

This is a device we previously repaired around 9 months ago for no power - in that instance we replaced one of the <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP>'s (UF400) as it was burned out which fixed the problem.

Same device has come back in for repair again - we have opened it up and found that UF400 has exploded completely - also there is evidence that the client has taken the device elsewhere as I couldn't find the missing pieces of UF400, heatsink was bent and multiple screws were missing all over the place. 

Anyhow back to the diagnosis and repair: 
Replaced UF400 with a <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP> from a donor board - board still stuck on 5V
Replaced UF400 with a brand new <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP> - board still stuck on 5V

Proceeded to check voltages: 
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_AON</SIGNAL> - 12V - seems too low to me but it's there
<SIGNAL>PP3V8_AON</SIGNAL> - 3.8V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S2</SIGNAL> - 3.2v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S2</SIGNAL> - 5v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S2_UPC</SIGNAL> - 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP1V25_S2</SIGNAL> - 1.25v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC0_LDO</SIGNAL> - 3.3v 
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC1_LDO</SIGNAL> - 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP1V5_UPC0_LDO_CORE</SIGNAL> - 1.5v 
<SIGNAL>PP1V5_UPC1_LDO_CORE</SIGNAL> - 1.5v
These voltages were all tested with the board out of the case with just the charger connected to the topmost type c port (Closest to display)

Plugged the macbook into another and opened apple configurator - it isn't coming up at all so doesn't seem to be in DFU mode. 

In terms of behaviour on the USB C Ammeter:
With Board out of case on its own:
Type C Port nearest display - 5V 0.26a then drops to 5V 0.05a
Other port - ammeter loops

With board installed in case and all parts connected:
Both Type C Ports - 5V 0.46A stable no looping.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Stuck at 5V 0.46A draw
threads.message:
If UF400 melt, very likely overvoltage from 20V to M1 occured.
M1 is connected directly to <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP> chips...
